centralQuestion: Will AI benefit the average skilled worker?

reasons.description: AI-driven tools significantly raise worker productivity, especially by automating routine tasks and acting as on‑the‑job digital assistants.

sources.title: Bloomberg News: "Generative AI Boosts Worker Productivity 14% in First Real‑World Study"
Reuters: "Will AI be an economic blessing or curse? History offers clues"

reasons.description: Demand for AI‑literate talent is pushing wages upward and widening opportunities for workers willing to upskill.

sources.title: Financial Times: "How a looming talent shortage threatens the AI boom"
Brookings Institution: "Using AI to advance skills‑first hiring"

reasons.description: AI lowers traditional barriers to expertise, empowering mid‑skill workers to tackle decision‑making and creative tasks once reserved for highly credentialed elites.

sources.title: The Washington Post: "AI could help ending the dominance of the credentialed classes"
Brookings Institution: "Generative AI, the American worker, and the future of work"

reasons.description: Some analyses find AI adoption improves job satisfaction and even health outcomes by offloading repetitive cognitive or physical strain.

sources.title: Reuters: "Will AI be an economic blessing or curse? History offers clues"

objections.description: Generative AI threatens to automate many mid‑skill roles, leading to outright displacement rather than augmentation.

sources.title: Financial Times: "Disrupted or displaced? How AI is shaking up jobs"
The Guardian: "The AI industrial revolution puts middle‑class workers under threat"

objections.description: AI may exacerbate wage inequality by funneling gains to capital owners and top‑skill specialists while eroding bargaining power for average workers.

sources.title: Economic Policy Institute: "Unbalanced labor market power is what makes technology harmful"
The Guardian: "AI will affect 40% of jobs and probably worsen inequality, says IMF"

objections.description: A skills‑gap risk looms: many incumbent mid‑career workers may lack the time or resources to acquire fast‑evolving AI skills.

sources.title: Financial Times: "How a looming talent shortage threatens the AI boom"
Brookings Institution: "Generative AI, the American worker, and the future of work"

objections.description: Some economists argue that AI’s productivity gains are overstated and may mirror Solow’s paradox—benefits accrue to a few firms, not broadly to workers.

sources.title: Bloomberg Opinion: "AI hype is proving to be Solow’s Paradox"

objections.description: Workplace AI can intensify surveillance, speed‑ups, and stress, undermining job quality for average skilled employees.

research.title: Generative AI at Work
research.description: Brynjolfsson, Li & Raymond (2023). A real‑world field study of 5,172 customer‑support agents showing a 15% average productivity boost, with the largest gains for lower‑skill workers.

research.title: Applying AI to Rebuild Middle‑Class Jobs
research.description: Autor (2024). Argues that carefully deployed AI could restore mid‑skill, middle‑income employment by complementing, not replacing, human expertise.

research.title: What Impact Has AI Had on Wage Inequality?
research.description: OECD (2024). Empirical analysis finds mixed effects—AI exposure lowered wage inequality in some professions but raised it in others, especially where skills were scarce.

research.title: AI Adoption and Inequality
research.description: International Monetary Fund Working Paper 25/068 (2025). Models suggest AI may reduce some wage gaps but substantially increase wealth inequality without policy intervention.

research.title: Augmenting or Automating Labor? The Effect of AI Development on Skill Demand
research.description: Zhang & co‑authors (2025). Finds automation‑oriented AI mainly substitutes low‑skill labor, while augmentation‑oriented AI benefits high‑skill roles; middle‑skill effects are mixed.
